Probably not, but still it's worth to ask...

Right now I have a long proof, proven parts of which I have commented out and replaced with sorry. All to make it faster/more comfortable proving remaining parts.
suffices is pretty much for this; refine can also be used for this by allowing you to define a metavariable for a goal and then case foo=> to a different goal first
Generally it is advisable to avoid long proofs. (Certainly <50 lines except in exceptional circumstances, and aiming for even 10 can be a good idea.) More preliminary lemmas is nearly always better!
(That said, if you are using a recent version of Lean tactic incrementality has made it much easier to work with very long proofs.)

Ouch, then what I'm doing is, probably, morally wrong or similarly. Right now I'm doing omega's job myself in the first part of the theorem Thm (which I'm going to rename to something adequate when finished) - here, more than 1000 lines.

It's nice meditative experience, as I don't have to hurry or smth. :sweat_smile:
(Probably should start learning how to write my own tactics...)
If you use stop instead of sorry, you may not need to comment out the rest of the branch. That said, definitely break up your proof in shorter lemmas!

The first half of the proof is simply like unfold definitions; split all ites <;> simp at * <;> omega, except omega have problems with many disjunctions in hypotheses, it seems, and becomes too slow for this use.

I have no idea how to replace that omega part with lemmas, except simply factoring them out. That would make proof the same length but with many more lemmas and kinda unmanageable.
Lessness has marked this topic as resolved.
